a series of actions which are designed to achieve something important
a United Nations programme to control the spread of AIDS
something that you watch on television or listen to on the radio
There’s a programme about killer whales next.
actions that have been planned to keep something in good condition or improve something
a small book or piece of paper that gives information about a play, concert etc and who the performers are
a series of planned activities or events, or a list showing what order they will come in
a programme of exhibitions throughout the year
a series of actions done in a particular order by a machine such as a washing machine
The light goes off when it finishes the programme.
programme.translation[0].note_box[0].hea: – Meaning 1: a series of actions which are designed to achieve something important
programme.translation[0].note_box[0].sec: The party did not have a clear economic programme.
This project is a central part of the development programme for the area.
After the elections, they embarked on an ambitious reform programme.
The company’s aggressive expansion program will double the size of the chain in the next four years.
We will continue with our hospital building programme.
The government’s spending programme is the subject of vigorous debate.
He was involved in the Soviet space programme.
A major programme of modernisation is transforming public transport in London.
The European Community embarked on an ambitious programme of research.
The company has embarked on an expansion programme.
They attempted to implement a programme of reform.
programme.translation[0].note_box[1].hea: – Meaning 2: something that you watch on television or listen to on the radio
programme.translation[0].note_box[1].sec: There aren't many good TV programmes on an the moment.
I was once interviewed for a radio programme.
More and more people are watching cookery programmes on TV.
She was watching a wildlife programme.
Did you see that programme last night about crocodiles?
A lot of people listen to that programme on the way to work.
I heard an interesting programme on the radio yesterday.
At the time she was also presenting several television programmes.
I was invited to appear on a TV programme.
programme.translation[0].note_box[2].sec: something that you watch on television, or listen to on the radio
I watched an interesting programme about Egypt last night.
a programme on television or the radio, especially an informal one in which people talk together, take part in a game etc
She hosts a weekly call-in radio show called ‘Got a question?’
a programme that gives you facts and information about a serious subject, such as history, science, or social problems
a television or radio programme that tells an imaginary story about a group of people and their lives, and is often broadcast regularly for many years
the huge success of television soaps
an amusing programme in which there is a different story each week about the same group of people
television programmes that show real people in funny situations or situations in which they must compete with each other. Often the people are filmed continuously for weeks or months
The trouble with reality TV is that a lot of the time it’s really boring.
a programme, event etc that is broadcast on the Internet
Universities may record and broadcast some lectures as webcasts.
a file of recorded sound and sometimes pictures that you can download from the Internet
The interview is available as a podcast.
to set a machine to operate in a particular way
The computers are programmed to search for key words and numbers.
to arrange for something to happen as part of a series of planned events or activities
an important plan that will be continued over a period of time
The airline is halfway through an expansion programme.
The commission is in favour of the auto investment programs.
the main satellite used to broadcast programmes into Latin America
to set a machine to work in a particular way
The system can be programmed to shut off the engine or stop it from restarting once the car is parked.
to arrange for something to happen as part of a series of planned events or activities
Cable TV operators generally agree that a well-programmed comedy network is an attractive asset.
